cold boot.md.rawJson:
{
  "protocol_version": "rb_session_v1",
  "session_id": "rb_20260208_201500",
  "tone": "friendly",
  "verbosity": "verbose",
  "summary": {
    "big_picture": "This piece nails a grimy-corporate, full-dive dystopia with a genuinely tender undercurrent: the craving for sensory truth, chosen family, and a space that feels unmonetized. Your best superpower here is contrast—greige office/apartment vs. the stormlit tavern—and you’re already using tactile detail (wind, puddles, warm smells) to make the “good place” feel dangerously real. The main opportunities are (1) smoothing a couple of viewpoint slips and tense jolts, (2) clarifying a few high-stakes concepts (RIF cycle, Zoo rules, the “kids” situation) so the reader doesn’t snag, and (3) tightening some lines that currently repeat beats you’ve already landed beautifully.",
    "what_improved": [
      "Flagged a few POV/tense slips where Jamie briefly becomes “Jamie” in third person.",
      "Suggested stronger, cleaner phrasing in places where emphasis stacks (italics + repetition + filler).",
      "Added transition beats to reduce whiplash between scenes (work → home → server → panic).",
      "Identified a couple of moments where character logic could read murky (kid avatars + fetish-server talk) and suggested clarity lines.",
      "Smoothed cadence in a handful of long sentences to keep the punchy voice you already have."
    ],
    "top_risks": [
      "Over-tightening could sand off the voicey, conversational charm (the asides and jokes are part of the flavor).",
      "Over-explaining server rules could reduce the alluring mystery of the Zoo (some ambiguity is doing good work).",
      "Too much sensory embellishment in the tavern section could slow momentum right when tension is ramping."
    ],
    "recommended_next_pass": "Do a single “POV/continuity sweep”: mark every place Jamie’s perception changes (work, home, Zoo, panic, back home) and ensure each scene has one clean entry beat, one grounding sensory anchor, and no accidental tense/name slips."
  },
  "doc_comments": [
    {
      "agent_id": "punch_agent",
      "severity": "suggestion",
      "comment": "Your contrasts are already sharp; the quickest punch upgrade is to trim a few “explaining sentences” that restate what your imagery has proven (greige, despair, corporate control). When you trust the sensory specifics, the satire hits harder and the tenderness reads cleaner.",
      "rationale": "You frequently land a strong image, then add a clarifying sentence that slightly softens the impact. Cutting or compressing those will keep the momentum and let the best lines ring.",
      "confidence": "high"
    },
    {
      "agent_id": "lens_agent",
      "severity": "important",
      "comment": "There are a couple of viewpoint/tense slips (Jamie briefly observed from the outside) that can momentarily break immersion in an otherwise very intimate voice. Fixing those will make the panic sequence and the ending flirtation with Geoff even more effective.",
      "rationale": "This story thrives on “I am inside the rig inside the world.” Any sudden third-person naming (“Jamie stared…”) reads like a camera cut you didn’t intend.",
      "confidence": "high"
    },
    {
      "agent_id": "rhythm_agent",
      "severity": "suggestion",
      "comment": "Your line-level music is strong (especially in the Zoo reveal), but some long sentences stack clauses in a way that blunts the snap of jokes and the creep of dread. A few strategic splits and one or two shorter stingers will give you even more control.",
      "rationale": "You’re already good at cadence; this is about giving the punchlines and the horror beats their own breathing room.",
      "confidence": "high"
    },
    {
      "agent_id": "adverb_killer",
      "severity": "nit",
      "comment": "You don’t overuse adverbs (yay), but a few “gently/just/really” moments could be swapped for stronger verbs or sensory specifics—especially in the early workplace section where you’re setting the baseline tone.",
      "rationale": "In dystopia, precision reads as authority. Replacing softeners with concrete action makes the world feel more inevitable.",
      "confidence": "medium"
    },
    {
      "agent_id": "transition_checker",
      "severity": "important",
      "comment": "Most transitions are clean and cinematic, but there are two spots where the reader may feel a sudden drop through a trapdoor: (1) the jump into the Zoo panic sequence, and (2) the cut back home where Anabelle appears via video and is suddenly in-room. A tiny bridge beat at each would make the flow seamless.",
      "rationale": "Because you’re writing about “loading,” “servers,” and “presence,” the reader expects transitions to be especially legible. A half-sentence of grounding can prevent confusion without slowing you down.",
      "confidence": "high"
    }
  ],
  "findings": [
    {
      "finding_id": "f_001",
      "agent_id": "punch_agent",
      "severity": "suggestion",
      "location": {
        "type": "anchor",
        "anchor_quote": "Virtual work hubs overclocked your brain, because capitalism couldn't leave well enough alone with eight hours of labor a day."
      },
      "comment": "This is a strong premise line, but it’s doing a lot in one breath. If you shave a clause, you’ll keep the bite and make it feel more inevitable—less like the narrator is explaining and more like they’re reporting a lived fact.",
      "rationale": "Punch lands best when the sentence feels inevitable, not argued.",
      "tradeoff": "Slightly less explicit political commentary; slightly more sting.",
      "confidence": "medium",
      "tags": [
        "pacing",
        "satire",
        "line-tightening"
      ],
      "suggestions": [
        "Option A: cut the explanatory clause and keep the image: let “overclocked your brain” carry the critique.",
        "Option B: split into two sentences for snap: one image, one stinger."
      ]
    },
    {
      "finding_id": "f_002",
      "agent_id": "adverb_killer",
      "severity": "nit",
      "location": {
        "type": "anchor",
        "anchor_quote": "The \"sun\"—as much as there could be sun in a virtual environment—cast a little warmth on my face."
      },
      "comment": "“A little warmth” is slightly soft/unspecific compared to how precise your sensory writing gets later (wind, rivulets, woodsmoke). Consider swapping for a more concrete sensation (prickly, skin-tight, artificial, etc.) so the reader feels the fakery.",
      "rationale": "Concrete sensation will reinforce your theme: simulated comfort vs. the real thing (your plants).",
      "tradeoff": "More specificity means committing to a particular “feel” of fake sun; but that’s a strength here.",
      "confidence": "medium",
      "suggestions": [
        "Try a sharper sensation word that implies “not real” (e.g., \"heat-lamp warmth,\" \"UV-tan tingle,\" \"plastic warmth\").",
        "Or keep \"little\" but add a telling detail: where it hits, how it fades."
      ]
    },
    {
      "finding_id": "f_003",
      "agent_id": "transition_checker",
      "severity": "suggestion",
      "location": {
        "type": "anchor",
        "anchor_quote": "Then she stood, stretched like a cat, and winked out of existence."
      },
      "comment": "Nice foreshadow (cat stretch!). If you want an even smoother on-ramp into the later reveal, you could add a micro-beat of Jamie watching her vanish and feeling the office “snap back” into greige—so the cut to home feels less like a hard scene break.",
      "rationale": "You’re using vanishing/loading as a motif; a tiny echo here strengthens the rhythm of your worldbuilding.",
      "tradeoff": "Adds 1–2 lines; minimal slowdown.",
      "confidence": "medium",
      "tags": [
        "transitions",
        "foreshadowing"
      ],
      "suggestions": [
        "After this sentence, add one short line like: “The cubicle lights hummed louder once she was gone.”",
        "Or: “Her absence was the only color the office couldn’t render.”"
      ]
    },
    {
      "finding_id": "f_004",
      "agent_id": "punch_agent",
      "severity": "suggestion",
      "location": {
        "type": "anchor",
        "anchor_quote": "Above, an all-seeing eye monitored my blood pressure and pulse in real-time so that the data could feed a model that decided what meds I was entitled to take."
      },
      "comment": "Great dystopian gut-punch. You can make it hit even harder by trimming the “so that” chain and letting the cruelty read as casual infrastructure.",
      "rationale": "The more mundane the horror, the sharper the horror.",
      "tradeoff": "Slightly less technical clarity; more emotional impact.",
      "confidence": "high",
      "tags": [
        "line-tightening",
        "impact"
      ],
      "suggestions": [
        "Consider compressing the cause/effect into one clean sentence with a hard final word (\"entitled\").",
        "Or split: one sentence for surveillance, one stinger for rationed meds."
      ]
    },
    {
      "finding_id": "f_005",
      "agent_id": "rhythm_agent",
      "severity": "nit",
      "location": {
        "type": "anchor",
        "anchor_quote": "I called him Stinky Pete."
      },
      "comment": "This lands as a good comic release. If you want it to pop even more, consider giving it a tiny beat of setup (a quick descriptor of the eye’s vibe) or a beat after (Jamie’s private satisfaction). Right now it’s funny; with one extra rhythmic beat it could be *iconic*.",
      "rationale": "Comedy loves timing: setup → punchline → micro-aftershock.",
      "tradeoff": "Adds a half-line; keep it tight so it doesn’t dull the snap.",
      "confidence": "medium",
      "suggestions": [
        "Add a brief setup phrase before: “The lens never blinked.”",
        "Or add a tag after: “It helped. Barely.”"
      ]
    },
    {
      "finding_id": "f_006",
      "agent_id": "lens_agent",
      "severity": "suggestion",
      "location": {
        "type": "anchor",
        "anchor_quote": "I took off my bra and slung it over Stinky's eye. (I could play it off as a mistake if anyone ever audited the film later.)"
      },
      "comment": "This is a fun defiant moment, but “audited the film” raises a clarity question: is her apartment recorded continuously in a way that’s later reviewed? If yes, that’s deliciously horrifying—worth one more concrete hint (who audits? employer? building?). If no, the aside could confuse.",
      "rationale": "High-stakes surveillance details are load-bearing worldbuilding; one extra noun can prevent reader wobble.",
      "tradeoff": "More specificity can make the world feel heavier; but your tone can carry it.",
      "confidence": "medium",
      "tags": [
        "clarity",
        "worldbuilding"
      ],
      "suggestions": [
        "Swap “audited the film” for a more specific watcher (\"compliance,\" \"benefits review,\" \"tenant oversight\").",
        "Or add one short clarifier elsewhere that apartments are recorded \"for safety\" (eyeroll)."
      ]
    },
    {
      "finding_id": "f_007",
      "agent_id": "transition_checker",
      "severity": "suggestion",
      "location": {
        "type": "anchor",
        "anchor_quote": "Then Stinky, my shitty dinner, and the world fell away for something new."
      },
      "comment": "This is a clean drop into the new server. If you want to heighten anticipation, consider adding one tiny “loading sensation” detail (the familiar fall, the click, the taste of metal) before the cut—so the next section’s atmosphere change feels like a deliberate inhale.",
      "rationale": "You’re writing full-dive: transitions are a sensory opportunity.",
      "tradeoff": "Adds one line; could slightly slow the briskness. Worth it if you want more immersion.",
      "confidence": "medium",
      "suggestions": [
        "Add a half-sentence about the jack’s coldness / the moment sound cuts out.",
        "Or a habitual ritual beat: counting breaths, tightening fists, etc."
      ]
    },
    {
      "finding_id": "f_008",
      "agent_id": "punch_agent",
      "severity": "suggestion",
      "location": {
        "type": "anchor",
        "anchor_quote": "It was a void where gentle, late-summer thunderstorms seemed to drag on forever."
      },
      "comment": "Love the mood, but “gentle” + “drag on forever” tug in opposite directions. If it’s gentle, “forever” can feel cozy; if it’s forever, it can feel oppressive. Decide which flavor you want (comforting liminality vs. eerie stasis) and sharpen the adjectives accordingly.",
      "rationale": "Aligned adjectives create a stronger emotional signal.",
      "tradeoff": "More decisive tone; less dreamy ambiguity.",
      "confidence": "medium",
      "suggestions": [
        "Cozy version: keep “gentle,” but make “forever” feel like relief (\"as if the storm had decided to stay\").",
        "Eerie version: drop “gentle” and lean into the unnatural persistence (\"patient,\" \"unblinking,\")"
      ]
    },
    {
      "finding_id": "f_009",
      "agent_id": "rhythm_agent",
      "severity": "nit",
      "location": {
        "type": "anchor",
        "anchor_quote": "The tavern didn’t load in like other spaces. It _revealed_ itself."
      },
      "comment": "This is a killer two-line cadence. Small note: you use italics a lot (it suits the voice), but this particular beat is already strong without emphasis. If you want to reserve italics for spikes of emotion, you could let “revealed” stand plain and trust the period break to do the work.",
      "rationale": "Strategic restraint makes emphasis more powerful later.",
      "tradeoff": "Slightly less typographic flair; more overall impact when italics appear.",
      "confidence": "low",
      "suggestions": [
        "Keep as-is if italics are part of the narrator’s signature.",
        "Or remove italics here and save them for the panic/no-logout moment."
      ]
    },
    {
      "finding_id": "f_010",
      "agent_id": "lens_agent",
      "severity": "important",
      "location": {
        "type": "anchor",
        "anchor_quote": "Jamie stared at her own reflection in a rain-streaked window."
      },
      "comment": "POV slip: you’ve been in first-person “I,” and here we suddenly get “Jamie” from the outside. It’s a small camera wobble, but it happens at a crucial anxiety spike. Consider converting this to first person to keep the panic intimate.",
      "rationale": "In a panic scene, distance reduces intensity; consistency boosts immersion.",
      "tradeoff": "None, really—this is a clean consistency fix.",
      "confidence": "high",
      "patch": {
        "type": "replace",
        "from": "Jamie stared at her own reflection in a rain-streaked window.",
        "to": "I stared at my own reflection in a rain-streaked window.",
        "risk": "low"
      }
    },
    {
      "finding_id": "f_011",
      "agent_id": "transition_checker",
      "severity": "important",
      "location": {
        "type": "anchor",
        "anchor_quote": "The voices at the bar shifted, doubled, blurred—  \nsomeone had antlers now, someone else unfurled wings, and a tiny child in the back became a full-grown bear between one blink and the next."
      },
      "comment": "This is a great “rules shift” moment, but it currently reads like a sudden montage without a clear trigger. One bridging clause can make it feel caused (Kat’s filter? Jack’s routine? the Zoo’s baseline?) rather than random, which will strengthen the dread of “No logout.”",
      "rationale": "Readers accept surreal escalation faster when you give them a single causal handle—even a mysterious one.",
      "tradeoff": "Slightly less dreamlike; much more controlled tension ramp.",
      "confidence": "high",
      "suggestions": [
        "Add a small trigger: Kat touching Jamie’s wrist, a filter “click,” the room “recompiling.”",
        "Or a line like: “Kat’s grin widened—and the code noticed me noticing.”"
      ]
    },
    {
      "finding_id": "f_012",
      "agent_id": "lens_agent",
      "severity": "suggestion",
      "location": {
        "type": "anchor",
        "anchor_quote": "and a tiny child in the back became a full-grown bear between one blink and the next."
      },
      "comment": "Given later concern about “kids involved,” the phrase “tiny child” may raise alarms you don’t intend (is that an actual minor, or just an avatar choice?). If your intent is “someone using a childlike avatar,” a small wording tweak can prevent the reader from assuming the worst.",
      "rationale": "You’re walking a delicate line: the story critiques boundaries and safety. Clarity helps you keep control of the reader’s conclusions.",
      "tradeoff": "A touch less shock value; a lot more trust.",
      "confidence": "medium",
      "suggestions": [
        "Swap to “a tiny kid-shaped avatar” or “a kid-sized avatar.”",
        "Or add a line elsewhere that age ≠ avatar (and that the Zoo enforces strict rules)."
      ]
    },
    {
      "finding_id": "f_013",
      "agent_id": "punch_agent",
      "severity": "suggestion",
      "location": {
        "type": "anchor",
        "anchor_quote": "\"Don't worry, they cleared me to be around people again, promise!\""
      },
      "comment": "This line is funny-dark and characterful, but it also risks making Jack feel flippant right when Jamie needs reassurance. If you want him to stay safe/grounding, consider adding a tiny sincerity tag (a softened look, a gentler tone) so the joke reads as coping, not dismissiveness.",
      "rationale": "Jack’s role here is emotional first aid. One micro-cue keeps him from reading like a walking red flag.",
      "tradeoff": "Less chaotic humor; more trust in Jack.",
      "confidence": "medium",
      "suggestions": [
        "Add a short beat: “He said it lightly, but his grip stayed steady.”",
        "Or tweak “promise!” to something calmer, letting the humor sit in the contrast."
      ]
    },
    {
      "finding_id": "f_014",
      "agent_id": "rhythm_agent",
      "severity": "suggestion",
      "location": {
        "type": "anchor",
        "anchor_quote": "\"I’m not—I’m not _like you people._ I’m just visiting.”"
      },
      "comment": "This is a strong, messy, human line (good!). Rhythm-wise, you might consider one of two approaches: either let the stutter stand and remove the italic emphasis (so it reads raw), or keep the emphasis but simplify the punctuation so the reader doesn’t stumble on the em-dash + repeated phrase + italics all at once.",
      "rationale": "In emotionally charged dialogue, too much typographic choreography can pull attention away from the feeling.",
      "tradeoff": "Less stylized text; more gut-level immediacy.",
      "confidence": "medium",
      "suggestions": [
        "Option A (raw): \"I’m not— I’m not like you. I’m just visiting.\"",
        "Option B (emphasis): keep italics but drop one interruption: \"I’m not like you people. I’m just visiting.\""
      ]
    },
    {
      "finding_id": "f_015",
      "agent_id": "transition_checker",
      "severity": "suggestion",
      "location": {
        "type": "anchor",
        "anchor_quote": "The rig beside my head chimed, and I answered. Voice and video only."
      },
      "comment": "The cut from “back in greige world” to Anabelle appearing “fully present” is cool, but the mechanics jump fast. One tiny bridge (e.g., Jamie routing the call through Stinky, enabling projection mode) will prevent a reader from thinking she re-entered the Zoo.",
      "rationale": "When your story’s tech is this central, small clarity beats prevent accidental confusion.",
      "tradeoff": "Adds 1 line; buys clarity.",
      "confidence": "high",
      "suggestions": [
        "Add a quick procedural line before/after: toggling projection, “room overlay,” etc.",
        "Or a sensory cue that distinguishes it from full-dive (flat audio, slight lag, no tactile feedback)."
      ]
    },
    {
      "finding_id": "f_016",
      "agent_id": "adverb_killer",
      "severity": "nit",
      "location": {
        "type": "anchor",
        "anchor_quote": "It was clean in the room again—antiseptic, almost, with all the clothes properly put away and the greige surfaces shimmering with freshly polished sheen."
      },
      "comment": "“almost,” “properly,” and “freshly” are doing a little softening work where your image is already strong. If you drop one or two, the line gets sharper and slightly more unsettling (as if the room cleaned itself *for* surveillance).",
      "rationale": "Reducing softeners increases creep and authority.",
      "tradeoff": "A bit less conversational; a bit more knife-edge.",
      "confidence": "medium",
      "suggestions": [
        "Consider removing “almost” or “properly” and letting “antiseptic” do the heavy lifting.",
        "Or swap one adverb for a concrete detail (a chemical smell, a faint ozone)."
      ]
    },
    {
      "finding_id": "f_017",
      "agent_id": "lens_agent",
      "severity": "suggestion",
      "location": {
        "type": "anchor",
        "anchor_quote": "For a moment I felt my world blur. The greige gave way to colorful, neon purple sharkskin."
      },
      "comment": "This is a *great* moment—your first bleed-through. To maximize its impact, consider clarifying whether the sensation is in her body (phantom skin) or in her vision (AR overlay), since she’s not currently jacked in. One noun can ground it: “my hands,” “my eyes,” “my reflection,” etc.",
      "rationale": "A tiny grounding detail makes the “uh-oh” feel real rather than abstract.",
      "tradeoff": "More concrete = less floaty; but this beat wants concrete.",
      "confidence": "high",
      "suggestions": [
        "Add where it manifests first: fingertips slick, skin tight, reflection shifting.",
        "Or add a line noting the rig is still chiming/connected, implying lingering routines."
      ]
    },
    {
      "finding_id": "f_018",
      "agent_id": "punch_agent",
      "severity": "suggestion",
      "location": {
        "type": "anchor",
        "anchor_quote": "\"Hand to God, I'd murder anyone who hurt the Kats. Especially that way.\""
      },
      "comment": "Emotionally understandable, but “I’d murder anyone…” is such a big escalation that it can yank the tone into melodrama for a second. If you want to keep the intensity without the tonal whiplash, you could swap to something equally fierce but less literal (or frame it as hyperbole in Jamie’s perception).",
      "rationale": "You’re building trust and boundaries. Keeping the line fierce-but-grounded helps the reader stay with Anabelle as “safe guide.”",
      "tradeoff": "Less shock; more credibility.",
      "confidence": "medium",
      "suggestions": [
        "Use a vow that’s intense but plausible: “I’d end them,” “I’d burn the place down,” “I’d ruin them.”",
        "Or add a small qualifier: “—she said, too fast, like she’d practiced saying it.”"
      ]
    },
    {
      "finding_id": "f_019",
      "agent_id": "rhythm_agent",
      "severity": "nit",
      "location": {
        "type": "anchor",
        "anchor_quote": "Those certainly were the days!"
      },
      "comment": "This is charmingly voicey, but it also briefly shifts into a nostalgic narrator tone that’s slightly different from Jamie’s usual bite. If you want it to feel fully in-character, consider making it a little more Jamie-specific (sour, wistful, funny).",
      "rationale": "Consistency of voice keeps the reader snug in the narrator’s head.",
      "tradeoff": "You lose a classic “narrator aside” vibe; you gain character intimacy.",
      "confidence": "low",
      "suggestions": [
        "Make it more Jamie: “Yeah. Those were the days.” or “Sure. The good old days.”",
        "Or tie it to plants/sunlight as Jamie’s specific longing."
      ]
    },
    {
      "finding_id": "f_020",
      "agent_id": "transition_checker",
      "severity": "suggestion",
      "location": {
        "type": "anchor",
        "anchor_quote": "Usually I'd let him struggle. But today, I guess meeting Kat had me feeling charitable."
      },
      "comment": "This is a nice “changed by experience” marker. If you want it to read even stronger, you could add a tiny echo of what Kat represented (boundaries, softness, chosen family), so the causality feels emotionally specific rather than generalized “charitable.”",
      "rationale": "Specific emotional cause makes character growth feel earned in micro-moments.",
      "tradeoff": "Adds a phrase; increases resonance.",
      "confidence": "medium",
      "suggestions": [
        "Add one adjective or image tie: “meeting Kat—sharp edges and all—” or “after the Zoo’s strange kindness—”.",
        "Or connect it to the drink’s “feeling of kindness” earlier."
      ]
    }
  ]
}
